In writing a Letter from Italy last March about prospects for the new Soelba government,
I said that the premier *s number one political probiim would probably be his own party.
On that occasion, I wrote* "Soelba*s success, or lade of it, will certainly hinge to a
great extent on how well Be Gasperi ... is able to hold the Christian Democracy in line
for him."
Bow Be Gasperi is gone and there is no one who can replace him and lesser men are doing
their best to hold the cover on a political pot that is simmering, if not yet boiling*
It is not only the Christian Democratic pot that is simmering, to be sure. The deep
split in the government-supporting Liberal party came to the surface again this summer when
three members of the loft faction resigned from the directorate. Some left-wing Social
Democrats are criticising their leader. Vice Premier Giuseppe Sarag&t, for being too vigor¬
ous in his defense of the Soelba government. Even in the tiny Republican party there is
dissension over whether it would be better actually to participate in the government or con¬
tinue the present policy of remaining aloof but supporting Soelba in parliament.
But it is the Christian Democracy — still by far the largest of Italy*s parties — that
holds the real power of life or death over the Scelba government* And therefore it is the
simmering in his own party that is causing Soelba his greatest concern*
Hhe strong man of the Christian Democracy is now Amintor© Fsnfeni, who belongs to a
different political generation than Soelba. Fenfani*s left-oenter "Democratic Initiative"
faction took decisive control of the party machinery at the national congress in Naples in
late June, not without leaving some political soars.
This development marked the end of one chapter in post-World War II Italian politics and
the beginning of smother* For the younger mne of the "Democratic Initiative" had come to
their majorities during the Fascist period and inevitably had been influenced by that fact.
The older followers of Be Gasperi, as I have said, came out of the old Popular party, with
its anti-fascist tradition. Mario Scelba was one of the youngest members of this Old Guard
and is virtually its only survivor still in high party and government position.
Fanfani took over the party secretaryship a month prior to Be Gasperi *s death, with the
official blessing of the elder statesman. But Be Gasperi remained by far the most influen¬
tial figure in the party.
As labor minister, agriculture minister and, finally, interior minister in the cabinets
of Be Gasperi and Pella, th© 46-year-old Fanfani demonstrated gre~t energy and administrative
ability* He has a flair for dramatizing causes and programs — and for not underplaying his
own role in them. Thus, a public housing program for workers, launched while he was labor
minister, became known as "the Fanfani program.” And thus a 3L-page booklet on th© land
reform program, issued while he was agriculture minister, contained no less than seven photo¬
graphs of Signor Fanfani.
These qualities unquestionably stand Fanfani in good stead as he ,^oes up and down the
Italian peninsula, trying to spark new enthusiasm and new organising efforts by the local
units of the Christian Democracy*
But Fanfani has yet to demonstrate the patience and the knack for promoting cohesion
that enabled Be Gasperi to hold the party together. In fact, he has the reputation for being
impatient — a young man in © hurry — and that has contributed to the current political
uneasiness and confusion.
